elements.content: A new Ca-MOF with the chemical formula of [Ca­(NO2-BDC)·DMF] n (MUT-1; NO2-BDC2– = 2-nitroterephthalate) with 5,5T4 topology and the Schäfli symbol of (48.62)­(45.65) was synthesized and structurally characterized with FT-IR, PXRD, BET, TG-DTA, and single-crystal X-ray techniques. MUT-1 has 1D channels along the crystallographic c axis. Its 1D channels have microporosity before the activation process, and its nanoporous structure can be achieved with the activation process. 1D channels of MUT-1 are surrounded by −NO2 groups, which indicate that this MOF could be a good candidate for CO2 storage. It shows 0.97 mmol g–1 of CO2 adsorption at 298 K up to 1 bar pressure. The structural stability of MUT-1 in various solvents was investigated, and a new phase after subsequent exposure to water and DMF was characterized.
elements.clean_text: A new Ca-MOF with the chemical formula of [Ca(NO2-BDC)⋅DMF] n  (MUT-1; NO2-BDC2- = 2-nitroterephthalate) with 5,5T4 topology and the Schäfli symbol of (48.62)(45.65) was synthesized and structurally characterized with FT-IR, PXRD, BET, TG-DTA, and single-crystal X-ray techniques. MUT-1 has 1D channels along the crystallographic c axis. Its 1D channels have microporosity before the activation process, and its nanoporous structure can be achieved with the activation process. 1D channels of MUT-1 are surrounded by -NO2 groups, which indicate that this MOF could be a good candidate for CO2 storage. It shows 0.97 mmol g-1 of CO2 adsorption at 298 K up to 1 bar pressure. The structural stability of MUT-1 in various solvents was investigated, and a new phase after subsequent exposure to water and DMF was characterized.

elements.content: A new Ca-MOF with the chemical formula of [Ca­(NO2-BDC)·DMF] n (MUT-1; NO2-BDC2− = 2-nitroterephthalate) with 5,5T4 topology and the Schäfli symbol of (48.62)­(45.65) was synthesized and structurally characterized with unique properties such as simple preparation, presence of 1D channels with micro- and nanoporosity before and after the activation process, respectively, presence of −NO2 groups in the pores, and ability for solid−liquid conversion. MUT-1 with −NO2 groups in its channels shows CO2 adsorption similar to that of ZIF-8 and ZIF-100 and higher than that MOF-2 and MOF-5, which have BDC2− linkers without any functional groups. MUT-1 is stable in dry organic solvents such as ethanol, methanol, and dichloromethane, but it is soluble in water and also, after treatment with H2O and DMF, transfers to a phase with a crystal structure similar to that of MIL-53­(Sc)-NO2 and MIL-53­(In)-Br-lp-DMF.

MUT-1 with -NO2 groups in its channels shows CO2 adsorption similar to that of ZIF-8 and ZIF-100 and higher than that MOF-2 and MOF-5, which have BDC2- linkers without any functional groups. MUT-1 is stable in dry organic solvents such as ethanol, methanol, and dichloromethane, but it is soluble in water and also, after treatment with H2O and DMF, transfers to a phase with a crystal structure similar to that of MIL-53(Sc)-NO2 and MIL-53(In)-Br-lp-DMF.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a new emerging class of crystalline hybrid material with unique properties such as large pore volume and high surface area that are used in many applications. They are appropriate candidates for use in catalysis, drug delivery, sensing, gas storage, antibacterial activity, and separation and as a template for the preparation of nanomaterials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a new emerging class of crystalline hybrid material with unique properties such as large pore volume and high surface area that are used in many applications. They are appropriate candidates for use in catalysis, drug delivery, sensing, gas storage, antibacterial activity, and separation and as a template for the preparation of nanomaterials.

elements.content: MOFs are built from metal ions as connectors and organic polyanions as linkers. There are different linkers, such as phosphonates, carboxylates, and sulfonates. Among them, aromatic carboxylate anions are of particular interest because of their strong coordination ability toward many metals and their rigid structure. The synthesis of MOFs based on alkaline-earth metals is a challenge because of the inherent difficulties in their formation and crystallization. Calcium is an eco-friendly, low-cost metal ion and is abundant in the Earth’s crust; therefore, preparation of MOFs with such metal ions can expand the scope of their applications. However, because of the multiplicity of coordination geometries and high coordination number of Ca2+ ions, the synthesis of Ca2+-based MOFs is not very simple. Ca2+ is a hard acid; therefore, a ligand with a carboxylate anion as a hard base is an appropriate linker. In comparison with transition-metal-based MOFs, there are relatively fewlow reported structures constructed from calcium.
elements.clean_text: MOFs are built from metal ions as connectors and organic polyanions as linkers. There are different linkers, such as phosphonates, carboxylates, and sulfonates. Among them, aromatic carboxylate anions are of particular interest because of their strong coordination ability toward many metals and their rigid structure. The synthesis of MOFs based on alkaline-earth metals is a challenge because of the inherent difficulties in their formation and crystallization. Calcium is an eco-friendly, low-cost metal ion and is abundant in the Earth's crust; therefore, preparation of MOFs with such metal ions can expand the scope of their applications. However, because of the multiplicity of coordination geometries and high coordination number of Ca2+ ions, the synthesis of Ca2+-based MOFs is not very simple. Ca2+ is a hard acid; therefore, a ligand with a carboxylate anion as a hard base is an appropriate linker. In comparison with transition-metal-based MOFs, there are relatively fewlow reported structures constructed from calcium.

elements.content: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is one of the greenhouse gases with the ability to cause many environmental problems. Porous solid materials such as MOFs as adsorbents are widely used in the CO2 capture process. Moreover, because CO2 is a molecule with a quadrupole moment, MOFs with polar pores decorated with −NH2, −OH, −NN–, −NC­(R)–, and NO2 moieties are useful in CO2 capture. In this work, the synthesis of a new Ca-based MOF constructed from Ca­(NO3)2·4H2O and 2-nitroterephthalic acid has been carried out and its crystal structure and properties such as stability in some solvents and CO2 adsorption potential have been investigated.
elements.clean_text: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is one of the greenhouse gases with the ability to cause many environmental problems. Porous solid materials such as MOFs as adsorbents are widely used in the CO2 capture process. Moreover, because CO2 is a molecule with a quadrupole moment, MOFs with polar pores decorated with -NH2, -OH, -NN-, -NC(R)-, and NO2 moieties are useful in CO2 capture. In this work, the synthesis of a new Ca-based MOF constructed from Ca(NO3)2⋅4H2O and 2-nitroterephthalic acid has been carried out and its crystal structure and properties such as stability in some solvents and CO2 adsorption potential have been investigated.

elements.content: The FT-IR spectra of MUT-1 and 2-nitroterephthalic acid are shown in Figure S1 in the Supporting Information. The two peaks at 1310 and 1699 cm–1 that are attributed to the free carboxylic acid group, ν­(C–O) and ν­(CO), respectively, in the free ligand are shifted to 1375 and 1600 cm–1 in MUT-1. The bands between 1340 and 1400 cm–1 are assigned to CC stretching of the aromatic ring in the ligand (NO2-H2BDC), the broad band at 3426 cm–1 corresponds to (sp2) C–H stretching in DMF, and the band corresponding to the carboxyl group of DMF appears at 1667 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

FT-IR Spectroscopy

The FT-IR spectra of MUT-1 and 2-nitroterephthalic acid are shown in Figure S1 in the Supporting Information. The two peaks at 1310 and 1699 cm-1 that are attributed to the free carboxylic acid group, ν(C-O) and ν(CO), respectively, in the free ligand are shifted to 1375 and 1600 cm-1 in MUT-1. The bands between 1340 and 1400 cm-1 are assigned to CC stretching of the aromatic ring in the ligand (NO2-H2BDC), the broad band at 3426 cm-1 corresponds to (sp2) C-H stretching in DMF, and the band corresponding to the carboxyl group of DMF appears at 1667 cm-1.

elements.content: The results of single-crystal X-ray diffraction confirmed that the structure of [Ca­(NO2-BDC)·DMF] n (MUT-1) is an extended 3D framework. It has a trigonal crystal system with R3c space group (). The asymmetric unit of MUT-1 consists of one Ca atom, one deprotonated NO2-BDC ligand, and one coordinated DMF molecule (a). The structure of MUT-1 consists of only one kind of calcium ion that is coordinated with seven oxygen atoms (O1, O2, 2 O3, 2 O4, and O7) and forms a distorted pentagonal bipyramid (b,c). Six oxygen atoms are from the NO2-BDC2– ligand and one oxygen atom is from the DMF molecule. Ca–O distances in the structure of MUT-1 are 2.28–2.57 Å (Table S1 in the Supporting Information). This range is similar to those of compounds with similar bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Analysis

The results of single-crystal X-ray diffraction confirmed that the structure of [Ca(NO2-BDC)⋅DMF] n  (MUT-1) is an extended 3D framework. It has a trigonal crystal system with R3c space group (). The asymmetric unit of MUT-1 consists of one Ca atom, one deprotonated NO2-BDC ligand, and one coordinated DMF molecule (a). The structure of MUT-1 consists of only one kind of calcium ion that is coordinated with seven oxygen atoms (O1, O2, 2 O3, 2 O4, and O7) and forms a distorted pentagonal bipyramid (b,c). Six oxygen atoms are from the NO2-BDC2- ligand and one oxygen atom is from the DMF molecule. Ca-O distances in the structure of MUT-1 are 2.28-2.57 Å (Table S1 in the Supporting Information). This range is similar to those of compounds with similar bonds.

elements.content: The distance between the centroids of of the aromatic rings is 4.982 Å (Figure S2a in the Supporting Information). Therefore, there is no π–π interaction between the phenolic rings of the adjacent ligands. The angle between two aromatic rings of the near ligands is 2.287° (Figure S2b in the Supporting Information). The 3D structure of MUT-1 along the crystallographic a, b, and c axes are shown in . MUT-1 has a 5,5T4 topology, and the Schäfli symbol of (48.62)­(45.65) has 1D channels along the crystallographic c axis ().

elements.content: Although DMF molecules are coordinated to metal sites through their oxygen atoms and occupied the pores, the structure of MUT-1 is microporous before the activation process and has 1D channels with a diameter of 8.0 Å (represented with a yellow circle in ). These 1D channels are along the crystallographic c axis, and its dimension is obtained by measuring the van der Waals radii of atoms by Diamond software. The 1D channels of MUT-1 in the absence of solvents have a diameter of 15.3 Å that is shown with an orange circle in (see also Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). The types of pores are classified on the basis of their diameter. Nanopores are in the range of 1–10 nm. Thus, we can consider MUT-1 as both a micro- and nanoporous MOF. The solvent-accessible volume was obtained as 1123.5 Å3 by olex2 software from the structural data without drying the MOF.

elements.content: The TG-DTA result is shown in . According to the results obtained, there are two main weight loss steps. The first weight loss is 23.8% from 65 to 200 °C, which corresponds to removal of coordinated DMF molecules that exist in the channels. On the basis of calculation, 22.7% of the molecular weight of MUT-1 consists of DMF molecules, which is similar to the results obtained from TG-DTA analysis (23.8%). This analysis also confirms that there is one DMF molecule per formula unit. The second step (about 59.0%) corresponds to the chemical decomposition of NO2-BDC2–, which starts at 200 °C and ends at 400 °C. The DTA curve of the compound displays two main exothermic peaks at 382 and 473 °C. These results show that the main step of the decomposition process occurs at 400 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Behavior

The TG-DTA result is shown in . According to the results obtained, there are two main weight loss steps. The first weight loss is 23.8% from 65 to 200 °C, which corresponds to removal of coordinated DMF molecules that exist in the channels. On the basis of calculation, 22.7% of the molecular weight of MUT-1 consists of DMF molecules, which is similar to the results obtained from TG-DTA analysis (23.8%). This analysis also confirms that there is one DMF molecule per formula unit. The second step (about 59.0%) corresponds to the chemical decomposition of NO2-BDC2-, which starts at 200 °C and ends at 400 °C. The DTA curve of the compound displays two main exothermic peaks at 382 and 473 °C. These results show that the main step of the decomposition process occurs at 400 °C.

elements.content: Thermal behavior of MUT-1.
elements.clean_text: 4  Thermal behavior of MUT-1.

elements.content: The BET surface area of MUT-1 before any activation was investigated. Crystals of MUT-1 were dried in the oven at 60 °C for 8 h. These crystals had a surface area of 1.315 m2 g–1 (). The N2 adsorption isotherm of MUT-1 before the activation process (a) showed that, at saturated pressure, MUT-1 can adsorb 1.05 cm3 g–1 of N2 gas. Activation of MUT-1 was carried out by a solvent exchange method. MUT-1 crystals were Soxhlet extracted with ethanol for 24 h. After the successful solvent exchange, crystals were heated in the vacuum oven at 80 °C for 24 h. The structural stability of MUT-1 after the activation process and removal of the coordinated solvents from its 1D channels were confirmed by PXRD analysis and 1H NMR spectroscopy, respectively (Figures S4 and S5 in the Supporting Information). The results obtained from N2 adsorption showed that MUT-1 has slightly accessible channels with a BET surface area of 28.173 m2 g–1 ( and b). The N2 adsorption isotherm (b) also showed that, at saturated pressure, an activated sample of MUT-1 can adsorb 83.58 cm3 g–1 of N2 gas. According to IUPAC classifications, this is a type V isotherm that is a particular type of adsorption in a micro- or mesoporous material. Also, there is a wide hysteresis in the N2 isotherm of MUT-1. On the basis of the IUPAC classifications of hysteresis loops, this MOF represents a type H3 hysteresis. This type of isotherm does not exhibit any limiting adsorption at high P/P 0. This type of hysteresis also represents that the desorption branch is delayed. The reasons can be due to various phenomena, such as pore blocking, cavitation, and strong adsorbate–adsorbent interactions in the MOF. The pore size distribution of MUT-1 before and after activation, evaluated using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method, is shown in Figure S6 in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
N2 Adsorption Isotherm

The BET surface area of MUT-1 before any activation was investigated. Crystals of MUT-1 were dried in the oven at 60 °C for 8 h. These crystals had a surface area of 1.315 m2 g-1 (). The N2 adsorption isotherm of MUT-1 before the activation process (a) showed that, at saturated pressure, MUT-1 can adsorb 1.05 cm3 g-1 of N2 gas. Activation of MUT-1 was carried out by a solvent exchange method. MUT-1 crystals were Soxhlet extracted with ethanol for 24 h. After the successful solvent exchange, crystals were heated in the vacuum oven at 80 °C for 24 h. The structural stability of MUT-1 after the activation process and removal of the coordinated solvents from its 1D channels were confirmed by PXRD analysis and 1H NMR spectroscopy, respectively (Figures S4 and S5 in the Supporting Information). The results obtained from N2 adsorption showed that MUT-1 has slightly accessible channels with a BET surface area of 28.173 m2 g-1 ( and b). The N2 adsorption isotherm (b) also showed that, at saturated pressure, an activated sample of MUT-1 can adsorb 83.58 cm3 g-1 of N2 gas. According to IUPAC classifications, this is a type V isotherm that is a particular type of adsorption in a micro- or mesoporous material. Also, there is a wide hysteresis in the N2 isotherm of MUT-1. On the basis of the IUPAC classifications of hysteresis loops, this MOF represents a type H3 hysteresis. This type of isotherm does not exhibit any limiting adsorption at high P/P 0. This type of hysteresis also represents that the desorption branch is delayed. The reasons can be due to various phenomena, such as pore blocking, cavitation, and strong adsorbate-adsorbent interactions in the MOF. The pore size distribution of MUT-1 before and after activation, evaluated using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, is shown in Figure S6 in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: One of the structural features of MUT-1 is the presence of nitro groups in the pores. The presence of this functional group with a polar nature can be suitable for interactions with the quadrupole moment of CO2 molecules. Therefore CO2 adsorption of MUT-1 was measured at 298 K up to 1 bar pressure (). The results obtained showed a maximum CO2 adsorption of 0.97 mmol g–1 at room temperature. This amount is comparable with those of some other reports that are given in . Its CO2 adsorption is similar to thta of ZIF-8 and ZIF-100 and higher than that of MOF-2 and MOF-5, which have no functional group on BDC2–. The Langmuir surface area of this MOF was also determined by CO2 sorption measurements at 298 K, which showed a surface area of 555 m2 g–1.
elements.clean_text:
CO2 Adsorption

One of the structural features of MUT-1 is the presence of nitro groups in the pores. The presence of this functional group with a polar nature can be suitable for interactions with the quadrupole moment of CO2 molecules. Therefore CO2 adsorption of MUT-1 was measured at 298 K up to 1 bar pressure (). The results obtained showed a maximum CO2 adsorption of 0.97 mmol g-1 at room temperature. This amount is comparable with those of some other reports that are given in . Its CO2 adsorption is similar to thta of ZIF-8 and ZIF-100 and higher than that of MOF-2 and MOF-5, which have no functional group on BDC2-. The Langmuir surface area of this MOF was also determined by CO2 sorption measurements at 298 K, which showed a surface area of 555 m2 g-1.

In order to study the stability of MUT-1 in different solvents, samples of the synthesized MOF were immersed in solvents for 3–4 days. Then they were heated in the oven at the temperature near the boiling point of the solvents to obtain an activated powder sample. In the case of water, it was observed that MUT-1 was soluble in it. This phenomenon is relatively rare in MOFs, and there are few reported MOFs with this property. A powder X-ray diffraction pattern (PXRD) of the ethanol-exchanged bulk material showed all significant peaks with appropriate matches with the simulated PXRD pattern. This result indicates the crystalline phase purity and structural stability of MUT-1 in dry ethanol. Some other solvents, including water, methanol, acetonitrile, and dichloromethane, were also investigated. MUT-1 is stable and insoluble in all of the solvents except water (Figure S7 in the Supporting Information). MUT-1 is soluble in water and is accompanied by a phase change (A phase). This change in the structure of MUT-1 can be attributed to dissolution/reorganization reactions, including Ca–O bond breaking and re-formation. An investigation of this new phase (the preparation method is explained in the Supporting Information) requires crystallographic studies on a single crystal of this MOF in water. However, unfortunately, the crystallization process of this compound in water was not successful. In an continuation of our previous work on investigating the structural conversion of MOFs and coordination polymers, in this case a comparison between the PXRD pattern of the A phase with those of other reported MOFs constructed from Ca2+ and terephthalic acid in the presence of water was done in order to find some similar patterns (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information). (1) A PXRD pattern (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information) that is attributed to a MOF with the formula [Ca­(BDC)­(DMF)­(H2O)] n formula was similar to that of the A phase. However, there are some differences that are represented in red. Therefore, this phase remains unknown. For more investigations of the A phase, some analyses such as FT-IR and TG-DTA were carried out (Figures S1 and S9 in the Supporting Information, respectively). The IR spectrum indicates a pattern similar to that of MUT-1, but the peak at 1667 cm–1 that is attributed to the carboxyl group of DMF molecules is reduced in the A phase and shows a smaller amount of DMF in the structure of the A phase. The TG-DTA result is in agreement with that of FT-IR and shows lower reduced weight (14.5%) in comparison with MUT-1 (23.8%) at about 200 °C. On the basis of a similar FT-IR spectrum and lower DMF content in the A phase, a compound with a chemical formula of [Ca­(NO2-BDC)·0.6DMF] n is proposed for the A phase. MUT-1 is stable up to 200 °C () and the A phase is stable up to 400 °C (Figure S9 in the Supporting Information). Thus, the A phase shows different thermal behavior and has higher thermal stability in comparison with MUT-1.

Structural Stability of MUT-1 in Different Solvents

In order to study the stability of MUT-1 in different solvents, samples of the synthesized MOF were immersed in solvents for 3-4 days. Then they were heated in the oven at the temperature near the boiling point of the solvents to obtain an activated powder sample. In the case of water, it was observed that MUT-1 was soluble in it. This phenomenon is relatively rare in MOFs, and there are few reported MOFs with this property. A powder X-ray diffraction pattern (PXRD) of the ethanol-exchanged bulk material showed all significant peaks with appropriate matches with the simulated PXRD pattern. This result indicates the crystalline phase purity and structural stability of MUT-1 in dry ethanol. Some other solvents, including water, methanol, acetonitrile, and dichloromethane, were also investigated. MUT-1 is stable and insoluble in all of the solvents except water (Figure S7 in the Supporting Information). MUT-1 is soluble in water and is accompanied by a phase change (A phase). This change in the structure of MUT-1 can be attributed to dissolution/reorganization reactions, including Ca-O bond breaking and re-formation. An investigation of this new phase (the preparation method is explained in the Supporting Information) requires crystallographic studies on a single crystal of this MOF in water. However, unfortunately, the crystallization process of this compound in water was not successful. In an continuation of our previous work on investigating the structural conversion of MOFs and coordination polymers, in this case a comparison between the PXRD pattern of the A phase with those of other reported MOFs constructed from Ca2+ and terephthalic acid in the presence of water was done in order to find some similar patterns (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information). (1) A PXRD pattern (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information) that is attributed to a MOF with the formula [Ca(BDC)(DMF)(H2O)] n  formula was similar to that of the A phase. However, there are some differences that are represented in red. Therefore, this phase remains unknown. For more investigations of the A phase, some analyses such as FT-IR and TG-DTA were carried out (Figures S1 and S9 in the Supporting Information, respectively). The IR spectrum indicates a pattern similar to that of MUT-1, but the peak at 1667 cm-1 that is attributed to the carboxyl group of DMF molecules is reduced in the A phase and shows a smaller amount of DMF in the structure of the A phase. The TG-DTA result is in agreement with that of FT-IR and shows lower reduced weight (14.5%) in comparison with MUT-1 (23.8%) at about 200 °C. On the basis of a similar FT-IR spectrum and lower DMF content in the A phase, a compound with a chemical formula of [Ca(NO2-BDC)⋅0.6DMF] n  is proposed for the A phase. MUT-1 is stable up to 200 °C () and the A phase is stable up to 400 °C (Figure S9 in the Supporting Information). Thus, the A phase shows different thermal behavior and has higher thermal stability in comparison with MUT-1.

This means that a second phase has been produced (B phase). The PXRD pattern of this new phase was compared with the simulated patterns of reported MOFs with NO2-BDC2– linkers. This comparison of PXRD patterns is shown in .

elements.content: shows that, during the conversion of MUT-1 to its B phase, the coordination behavior of NO2-BDC2– (a) and coordination sphere of Ca2+ (b) changed. a shows that, in MUT-1 and its B phase, one of the carboxylate groups of NO2-BDC2– has the same coordination behavior, but the μ3-η1:η2:η1 coordination behavior of the second carboxylate group in MUT-1 changes to a μ2-η1:η bridging mode in the B phase during exposure to water and DMF solvents subsequently. Actually, in the B phase the NO2-BDC2– ligand bridges four Ca2+ ions by its four O atoms and acts as a 4-fold-donor ligand. Thus, the two carboxylate groups adopt a μ2-η1:η1 bridging coordination mode in the B phase. b indicates that the Ca atom in MUT-1 with a CaO7 distorted-pentagonal-bipyramidal coordination sphere changes to a CaO4 tetrahedral coordination sphere in the B phase during subsequent exposure to water and DMF solvents.

Actually, in the B phase the NO2-BDC2- ligand bridges four Ca2+ ions by its four O atoms and acts as a 4-fold-donor ligand. Thus, the two carboxylate groups adopt a μ2-η1:η1 bridging coordination mode in the B phase. b indicates that the Ca atom in MUT-1 with a CaO7 distorted-pentagonal-bipyramidal coordination sphere changes to a CaO4 tetrahedral coordination sphere in the B phase during subsequent exposure to water and DMF solvents.

elements.content: In summary, a new calcium-based MOF, [Ca­(NO2-BDC)·DMF] n (MUT-1), with 5,5T4 topology and the Schäfli symbol of (48.62)­(45.65) was synthesized and structurally characterized by the single-crystal X-ray technique. MUT-1 can be considered as both a micro- and nanoporous MOF. To the best of our knowledge, MUT-1 is first MOF with this unique structural feature. MUT-1 shows 21.45 cm3 g–1 (0.97 mmol.g–1) CO2 adsorption at 298 K up to 1 bar pressure. Its CO2 adsorption is similar to that of ZIF-8 and ZIF-100 and higher than that of MOF-2 and MOF-5, which has BDC2– linkers with no functional groups. MUT-1 is stable in dry solvents such as ethanol, methanol, and dichloromethane, but it is soluble in water and also transfers to a new phase (A). A comparison between the PXRD pattern of the A phase with those of other reported MOFs from Ca2+ and BDC2– indicated that the A phase may have a structure similar to that of [Ca­(BDC)­(DMF)­(H2O)] n . The phase in DMF changes to another phase (B) whose PXRD pattern is exactly the same as those of MIL-53­(Sc)-NO2 and MIL-53­(In)-NO2-lp-DMF. Thus, the NO2-BDC2– coordination behavior and Ca2+ coordination sphere changes during subsequent exposure of MUT-1 to H2O and DMF solvents can be explained.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a new calcium-based MOF, [Ca(NO2-BDC)⋅DMF] n  (MUT-1), with 5,5T4 topology and the Schäfli symbol of (48.62)(45.65) was synthesized and structurally characterized by the single-crystal X-ray technique. MUT-1 can be considered as both a micro- and nanoporous MOF. To the best of our knowledge, MUT-1 is first MOF with this unique structural feature. MUT-1 shows 21.45 cm3 g-1 (0.97 mmol.g-1) CO2 adsorption at 298 K up to 1 bar pressure. Its CO2 adsorption is similar to that of ZIF-8 and ZIF-100 and higher than that of MOF-2 and MOF-5, which has BDC2- linkers with no functional groups. MUT-1 is stable in dry solvents such as ethanol, methanol, and dichloromethane, but it is soluble in water and also transfers to a new phase (A). A comparison between the PXRD pattern of the A phase with those of other reported MOFs from Ca2+ and BDC2- indicated that the A phase may have a structure similar to that of [Ca(BDC)(DMF)(H2O)] n . The phase in DMF changes to another phase (B) whose PXRD pattern is exactly the same as those of MIL-53(Sc)-NO2 and MIL-53(In)-NO2-lp-DMF. Thus, the NO2-BDC2- coordination behavior and Ca2+ coordination sphere changes during subsequent exposure of MUT-1 to H2O and DMF solvents can be explained.

elements.content: All chemicals were used as commercially obtained without further purification. IR spectra were recorded using an Equinox 55 FT-IR spectrometer (Bruker, Bremen, Germany) in ATR form, in the range of 400–4000 cm–1 with 4.0 cm–1 resolution and 16 scans. Melting point results were obtained with an Electrothermal 9100 apparatus. The TG/DTA measurements were carried out with a STA504 apparatus between 20 and 800 °C, at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1, under a nitrogen atmosphere. The specific surface area, pore size, and volume of MUT-1 were determined by Belsorp mini II (Japan). Micromeritics TriStar II Plus was used to measure CO2 adsorption isotherm. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed using a Rigaku ultima IV diffractometer with monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.02° and a 2θ range of 3.0–50°. Simulated XRD powder patterns based on single-crystal data were prepared using Mercury software. The intensity data of [Ca­(NO2-BDC)·DMF] n were collected with an Oxford Diffraction SuperNova CCD diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. The temperature during data collections was kept at 130.00(10) K using an Oxford Cryosystems cooling device. The structure was solved by direct methods and difference Fourier synthesis. All H atoms were positioned geometrically. Structure visualization of the MOF was carried out using the Mercury, ToposPro, and Diamond programs. The calculation of solvent-accessible voids was done by the Olex2 program with a 0.2 Å grid size and 1.2 Å probe. Determination of the topology was done by TOPOS Pro software.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Techniques

All chemicals were used as commercially obtained without further purification. IR spectra were recorded using an Equinox 55 FT-IR spectrometer (Bruker, Bremen, Germany) in ATR form, in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 with 4.0 cm-1 resolution and 16 scans. Melting point results were obtained with an Electrothermal 9100 apparatus. The TG/DTA measurements were carried out with a STA504 apparatus between 20 and 800 °C, at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1, under a nitrogen atmosphere. The specific surface area, pore size, and volume of MUT-1 were determined by Belsorp mini II (Japan). Micromeritics TriStar II Plus was used to measure CO2 adsorption isotherm. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed using a Rigaku ultima IV diffractometer with monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.02° and a 2θ range of 3.0-50°. Simulated XRD powder patterns based on single-crystal data were prepared using Mercury software. The intensity data of [Ca(NO2-BDC)⋅DMF] n  were collected with an Oxford Diffraction SuperNova CCD diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. The temperature during data collections was kept at 130.00(10) K using an Oxford Cryosystems cooling device. The structure was solved by direct methods and difference Fourier synthesis. All H atoms were positioned geometrically. Structure visualization of the MOF was carried out using the Mercury, ToposPro, and Diamond programs. The calculation of solvent-accessible voids was done by the Olex2 program with a 0.2 Å grid size and 1.2 Å probe. Determination of the topology was done by TOPOS Pro software.

elements.content: A 0.5 mmol portion of Ca­(NO3)2·4H2O and 0.5 mmol of 2-nitroterephthalic acid (NO2-H2BDC) were dissolved in 7 mL of DMF and stirred for 5 min. Then the clear solution was placed in a glass vial and heated in the oven at 120 °C overnight. After this time pale yellow crystals of MUT-1 (MUT: Materials from University of Tehran) with rod shapes appeared at the bottom of the vial. Dec pt: over 300 °C. Yield: 58.7% (based on final product).

After this time pale yellow crystals of MUT-1 (MUT: Materials from University of Tehran) with rod shapes appeared at the bottom of the vial. Dec pt: over 300 °C. cln_elements.content:
A new Ca-MOF with the chemical formula of [Ca­(NO2-BDC)·DMF] n (MUT-1; NO2-BDC2– = 2-nitroterephthalate) with 5,5T4 topology and the Schäfli symbol of (48.62)­(45.65) was synthesized and structurally characterized with FT-IR, PXRD, BET, TG-DTA, and single-crystal X-ray techniques. MUT-1 has 1D channels along the crystallographic c axis. Its 1D channels have microporosity before the activation process, and its nanoporous structure can be achieved with the activation process. 1D channels of MUT-1 are surrounded by −NO2 groups, which indicate that this MOF could be a good candidate for CO2 storage. It shows 0.97 mmol g–1 of CO2 adsorption at 298 K up to 1 bar pressure. The structural stability of MUT-1 in various solvents was investigated, and a new phase after subsequent exposure to water and DMF was characterized.

Single-Crystal X-ray Analysis

The results of single-crystal X-ray diffraction confirmed that the structure of [Ca­(NO2-BDC)·DMF] n (MUT-1) is an extended 3D framework. It has a trigonal crystal system with R3c space group (). The asymmetric unit of MUT-1 consists of one Ca atom, one deprotonated NO2-BDC ligand, and one coordinated DMF molecule (a). The structure of MUT-1 consists of only one kind of calcium ion that is coordinated with seven oxygen atoms (O1, O2, 2 O3, 2 O4, and O7) and forms a distorted pentagonal bipyramid (b,c). Six oxygen atoms are from the NO2-BDC2– ligand and one oxygen atom is from the DMF molecule. Ca–O distances in the structure of MUT-1 are 2.28–2.57 Å (Table S1 in the Supporting Information). This range is similar to those of compounds with similar bonds.

Although DMF molecules are coordinated to metal sites through their oxygen atoms and occupied the pores, the structure of MUT-1 is microporous before the activation process and has 1D channels with a diameter of 8.0 Å (represented with a yellow circle in ). These 1D channels are along the crystallographic c axis, and its dimension is obtained by measuring the van der Waals radii of atoms by Diamond software. The 1D channels of MUT-1 in the absence of solvents have a diameter of 15.3 Å that is shown with an orange circle in (see also Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). The types of pores are classified on the basis of their diameter. Nanopores are in the range of 1–10 nm. Thus, we can consider MUT-1 as both a micro- and nanoporous MOF. The solvent-accessible volume was obtained as 1123.5 Å3 by olex2 software from the structural data without drying the MOF.

Thermal Behavior

The TG-DTA result is shown in . According to the results obtained, there are two main weight loss steps. The first weight loss is 23.8% from 65 to 200 °C, which corresponds to removal of coordinated DMF molecules that exist in the channels. On the basis of calculation, 22.7% of the molecular weight of MUT-1 consists of DMF molecules, which is similar to the results obtained from TG-DTA analysis (23.8%). This analysis also confirms that there is one DMF molecule per formula unit. The second step (about 59.0%) corresponds to the chemical decomposition of NO2-BDC2–, which starts at 200 °C and ends at 400 °C. The DTA curve of the compound displays two main exothermic peaks at 382 and 473 °C. These results show that the main step of the decomposition process occurs at 400 °C.

N<sub>2</sub> Adsorption Isotherm

The BET surface area of MUT-1 before any activation was investigated. Crystals of MUT-1 were dried in the oven at 60 °C for 8 h. These crystals had a surface area of 1.315 m2 g–1 (). The N2 adsorption isotherm of MUT-1 before the activation process (a) showed that, at saturated pressure, MUT-1 can adsorb 1.05 cm3 g–1 of N2 gas. Activation of MUT-1 was carried out by a solvent exchange method. MUT-1 crystals were Soxhlet extracted with ethanol for 24 h. After the successful solvent exchange, crystals were heated in the vacuum oven at 80 °C for 24 h. The structural stability of MUT-1 after the activation process and removal of the coordinated solvents from its 1D channels were confirmed by PXRD analysis and 1H NMR spectroscopy, respectively (Figures S4 and S5 in the Supporting Information). The results obtained from N2 adsorption showed that MUT-1 has slightly accessible channels with a BET surface area of 28.173 m2 g–1 ( and b). The N2 adsorption isotherm (b) also showed that, at saturated pressure, an activated sample of MUT-1 can adsorb 83.58 cm3 g–1 of N2 gas. According to IUPAC classifications, this is a type V isotherm that is a particular type of adsorption in a micro- or mesoporous material. Also, there is a wide hysteresis in the N2 isotherm of MUT-1. On the basis of the IUPAC classifications of hysteresis loops, this MOF represents a type H3 hysteresis. This type of isotherm does not exhibit any limiting adsorption at high P/P 0. This type of hysteresis also represents that the desorption branch is delayed. The reasons can be due to various phenomena, such as pore blocking, cavitation, and strong adsorbate–adsorbent interactions in the MOF. The pore size distribution of MUT-1 before and after activation, evaluated using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method, is shown in Figure S6 in the Supporting Information.

CO<sub>2</sub> Adsorption

One of the structural features of MUT-1 is the presence of nitro groups in the pores. The presence of this functional group with a polar nature can be suitable for interactions with the quadrupole moment of CO2 molecules. Therefore CO2 adsorption of MUT-1 was measured at 298 K up to 1 bar pressure (). The results obtained showed a maximum CO2 adsorption of 0.97 mmol g–1 at room temperature. This amount is comparable with those of some other reports that are given in . Its CO2 adsorption is similar to thta of ZIF-8 and ZIF-100 and higher than that of MOF-2 and MOF-5, which have no functional group on BDC2–. The Langmuir surface area of this MOF was also determined by CO2 sorption measurements at 298 K, which showed a surface area of 555 m2 g–1.

Structural Stability of MUT-1 in Different Solvents

In order to study the stability of MUT-1 in different solvents, samples of the synthesized MOF were immersed in solvents for 3–4 days. Then they were heated in the oven at the temperature near the boiling point of the solvents to obtain an activated powder sample. In the case of water, it was observed that MUT-1 was soluble in it. This phenomenon is relatively rare in MOFs, and there are few reported MOFs with this property. A powder X-ray diffraction pattern (PXRD) of the ethanol-exchanged bulk material showed all significant peaks with appropriate matches with the simulated PXRD pattern. This result indicates the crystalline phase purity and structural stability of MUT-1 in dry ethanol. Some other solvents, including water, methanol, acetonitrile, and dichloromethane, were also investigated. MUT-1 is stable and insoluble in all of the solvents except water (Figure S7 in the Supporting Information). MUT-1 is soluble in water and is accompanied by a phase change (A phase). This change in the structure of MUT-1 can be attributed to dissolution/reorganization reactions, including Ca–O bond breaking and re-formation. An investigation of this new phase (the preparation method is explained in the Supporting Information) requires crystallographic studies on a single crystal of this MOF in water. However, unfortunately, the crystallization process of this compound in water was not successful. In an continuation of our previous work on investigating the structural conversion of MOFs and coordination polymers, in this case a comparison between the PXRD pattern of the A phase with those of other reported MOFs constructed from Ca2+ and terephthalic acid in the presence of water was done in order to find some similar patterns (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information). (1) A PXRD pattern (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information) that is attributed to a MOF with the formula [Ca­(BDC)­(DMF)­(H2O)] n formula was similar to that of the A phase. However, there are some differences that are represented in red. Therefore, this phase remains unknown. For more investigations of the A phase, some analyses such as FT-IR and TG-DTA were carried out (Figures S1 and S9 in the Supporting Information, respectively). The IR spectrum indicates a pattern similar to that of MUT-1, but the peak at 1667 cm–1 that is attributed to the carboxyl group of DMF molecules is reduced in the A phase and shows a smaller amount of DMF in the structure of the A phase. The TG-DTA result is in agreement with that of FT-IR and shows lower reduced weight (14.5%) in comparison with MUT-1 (23.8%) at about 200 °C. On the basis of a similar FT-IR spectrum and lower DMF content in the A phase, a compound with a chemical formula of [Ca­(NO2-BDC)·0.6DMF] n is proposed for the A phase. MUT-1 is stable up to 200 °C () and the A phase is stable up to 400 °C (Figure S9 in the Supporting Information). Thus, the A phase shows different thermal behavior and has higher thermal stability in comparison with MUT-1.

Conclusions

In summary, a new calcium-based MOF, [Ca­(NO2-BDC)·DMF] n (MUT-1), with 5,5T4 topology and the Schäfli symbol of (48.62)­(45.65) was synthesized and structurally characterized by the single-crystal X-ray technique. MUT-1 can be considered as both a micro- and nanoporous MOF. To the best of our knowledge, MUT-1 is first MOF with this unique structural feature. MUT-1 shows 21.45 cm3 g–1 (0.97 mmol.g–1) CO2 adsorption at 298 K up to 1 bar pressure. Its CO2 adsorption is similar to that of ZIF-8 and ZIF-100 and higher than that of MOF-2 and MOF-5, which has BDC2– linkers with no functional groups. MUT-1 is stable in dry solvents such as ethanol, methanol, and dichloromethane, but it is soluble in water and also transfers to a new phase (A). A comparison between the PXRD pattern of the A phase with those of other reported MOFs from Ca2+ and BDC2– indicated that the A phase may have a structure similar to that of [Ca­(BDC)­(DMF)­(H2O)] n . The phase in DMF changes to another phase (B) whose PXRD pattern is exactly the same as those of MIL-53­(Sc)-NO2 and MIL-53­(In)-NO2-lp-DMF. Thus, the NO2-BDC2– coordination behavior and Ca2+ coordination sphere changes during subsequent exposure of MUT-1 to H2O and DMF solvents can be explained.
